plants.name: Echinacea purpurea
plants.description: A hardy perennial native to North America, known for its large daisy-like purple flowers and prominent cone-shaped centers. It attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies and is often used in herbal remedies.
plants.funFact: Echinacea has been traditionally used by Native Americans for its medicinal properties, especially to support the immune system.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: A tuberous perennial native to Mexico, notable for its wide range of flower forms and colors. Dahlias produce large, showy blooms that often appear in late summer and early fall, making them popular in gardens and floral arrangements.
plants.location: Mexico and widely cultivated in temperate zones worldwide
plants.funFact: Dahlias are the national flower of Mexico and have over 42 species growing wild in the country.

plants.name: Solidago canadensis
plants.description: A perennial wildflower with dense clusters of small yellow flowers. It is native to North America and blooms in late summer and early fall, often signaling the arrival of autumn.
plants.location: North America, especially Canada and United States
plants.funFact: Goldenrod is an important late-season nectar source for bees and butterflies.

plants.name: Camellia sasanqua
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to Japan, known for its smaller, fragrant flowers that bloom from early fall into winter. It is often used for ornamental purposes in gardens and is prized for its glossy leaves and extended blooming period.
plants.location: Japan and cultivated in temperate regions
plants.funFact: Sasanqua camellias bloom in autumn, providing color and fragrance when many other plants have finished flowering.
